channel.title: English Editorial Combined Feed
channel.description: Aggregated English editorial feed without duplicates

item.title: Palestine’s recognition is not a reward to Hamas
item.description: Western media's coverage of Palestine's recognition is anything but an unbelievably shameful dehumanisation of the Palestinian people.

item.title: Prioritising generation of solar energy
item.description: There is a race among many countries, barring those which have huge fossil fuel reserves, for transition to renewable energy. In fact, if the planet Earth has to meet the challenges posed by the global warming, the option for such a transition is overriding. Dependence on fossil fuel is aggravating

item.title: Stolen asset recovery demands resolve, not rhetoric
When farmers become shadows
Brain drain from South Asia: what to do?
item.description: Brain drain refers to the emigration of skilled persons from developing countries to developed countries. A large numbers of highly educated South Asians, especially from India, Pakistan, Bangladesh and Sri Lanka, have migrated to developed countries such as the United Kingdom (UK), the United Stat

item.title: Preserving the dark memory of torture
item.description: Every country carries a thick book of sorrow-some hidden in secrecy, others etched on history as an eternal reminder to generations yet unborn. For Bangladesh, a country born out of the 1971 war of liberation and genocide, its heritage of suffering is inseparable from its struggle for freedom. Agai

item.title: Choice before Lanka government
Divorcing science to embrace what?
Reading the 1969 uprising across time
Recognition of Palestine: statement or substance?
Isn’t Hindutva embarrassing India?
Govt should ensure justice for Milestone disaster victims
Modernising waste management
Menace of indiscriminate road digging must end
Trump’s Effort to Pick America’s Corporate Winners Will End Badly
item.description: In his second term, US President Donald Trump has abandoned America’s free-market tradition, importing the failed playbook of state-controlled economies. Far from delivering prosperity, heavy-handed government interference will throw good money after bad, distort competition, and prop up failing firms.

item.title: On Climate Change, the Market Is Wrong Again
item.description: In our fast-changing physical world, complacency in the face of climate risks could be catastrophically wrong. The 2008 global financial crisis showed that financial markets and regulators are perfectly capable of neglecting major threats, only this time there will be no one on the winning side of a short bet.

item.title: The US Is Winning the AI Race - But for How Long?
item.description: While global power once rested on armies, natural resources, and control of sea and air, it now also depends on the data, talent, and digital infrastructure needed to develop and deploy cutting-edge AI models. The US is currently in the lead, but China, Europe, and other rising powers are moving quickly to close the gap.

item.title: The High Cost of Defunding Women’s Organizations
item.description: Women’s rights organizations fight not only for gender equality but also for the very freedoms that sustain democracy and allow citizens to hold leaders accountable. But as funding dries up, their ability to sustain this vital work is weakening.

item.title: Turning the Tide Back Toward Peace in the Middle East
item.description: At this year's United Nations General Assembly, the international community must recognize its collective responsibility to end the spiral of violence in the Middle East. This is the moment to start generating positive dynamics in favor of the only viable solution: an Israeli and Palestinian state, side by side.

item.title: A Made-in-China plan for world domination
item.description: Donald Trump is failing to stop China’s rise as a manufacturing superpower

item.title: Resuming the agro-goods train services
item.description: Rail transportation of agricultural products provides cost efficiency, bulk shipments, reduced transit congestion, and minimised spoilage of perishable items. Despite these advantages, the newly launched weekly train services for agricultural goods, which commenced in October 2024, were suspended j

item.description: Although the number of dengue infections this year has exceeded last year’s total, the overall mortality rate remains relatively lower.

item.title: When the World Suffers Dengue, Bangladesh Feels the Worst
Why Bangladesh must legislate AI before it’s too late
How Gender Equality Boosts Economic Growth
item.description: While the relevance of race or other identity-based barriers to economic productivity varies across contexts, gender is a universal issue. Simply by ensuring that women can fully use their skills and talents, policymakers in countries at all levels of economic development can unlock substantial economic gains.

item.title: From cash to clicks: The digital transition of Bangladesh
The Key to Africa’s Clean-Energy Future
item.description: As a recent project to connect thousands of homes and businesses in Nigeria to solar power has demonstrated, modest investments can achieve dramatic advances in clean energy across the developing world. These projects' success depends on a coalition of public, private, and philanthropic partners united by a shared goal.

item.description: Scientists studying any link between the painkiller and autism have reached no firm conclusions

item.title: Violence Against Health Workers Must End
item.description: The World Health Organization estimates that as many as 38% of health-care workers suffer some form of physical violence, perpetrated mostly by patients and visitors, at some point in their careers. This harms not only the workers, but also the health of the populations they serve.

item.title: AI Is Pointless If It Doesn’t Boost Productivity
item.description: If all those pushing AI want it to serve society, they should develop a serious, clear, evidence-based plan to ensure that the technology contributes to productivity growth where it is needed most. Otherwise, we all must ask what the current massive sums of investment are for.

item.title: Submerged every rainfall

SMEs are a lifeline to Bangladesh

item.title: Adding meaning to the recognition of Palestine
item.description: Finally, the United Kingdom, Canada and Australia have given formal recognition to the state of Palestine on Sunday, September 21. The three staunch supporters of Israel-they still are-have decided to accept the Palestinian people's right to statehood. So, what prompted the British Prime Minister K

item.title: Health Taxes Are a Win-Win
item.description: The sudden withdrawal of foreign aid has accelerated the shift toward self-sufficient health systems in Global South countries, even as they face a non-communicable disease epidemic. Fortunately, world leaders can address both issues by committing to health taxes at this week’s United Nations General Assembly.

item.title: Clean Energy Is Inevitable Despite Trump
item.description: The world is not on track to meet its climate targets, and the devastating effects of global warming are appearing faster than many anticipated. But the undeniable progress made in the Paris climate agreement's first decade provides reason to hope that more progress can be made.

item.title: Government Shutdowns and America’s Broken Democracy
item.description: The US does not face the specter of a government shutdown every September because of policy disagreements or financial constraints. Rather, democratic accountability has been so eroded that elected officials have no incentive to compromise – to do the hard work of politics – and devise real solutions that serve ordinary Americans.

item.title: PS Events: The Green Development Agenda
What a Mission-Oriented Approach to School Meals Could Do
item.description: School-meal programs are about more than expanding welfare provisions and providing basic nutrition to vulnerable children. When designed properly and incorporated into broader industrial strategies, they represent a powerful opportunity to transform entire food systems and advance other development goals.

item.title: Post-LDC strategy: Unlocking export potential of GI products through diversification
Trump’s Show of Force
item.description: The deployment of federal troops to US cities is the political equivalent of a lit fuse, increasing the likelihood of an incident – a service member’s suicide, a friendly-fire incident, the shooting of a protester – that can be used to manufacture some greater crisis. It is up to citizens, and especially state governments, to resist.

item.title: The Polycrisis Demands a Renewed Humanism
item.description: In the third decade of the twenty-first century, we are facing a confluence of escalating ecological, political, economic, technological, and existential crises, each of which is reinforcing the others. The situation requires a fundamentally different set of values, not mere technocratic fixes.

item.description: At his memorial in Arizona, top Republicans hailed him as a martyr

item.title: When innovation is not a priority
item.description: Economists often describe innovation as the key driver of economic growth, and rightly so. While land, labour and capital have long been considered the fundamental inputs of production, it is innovation that transforms these resources into engines of prosperity. item.title: North Africa’s Scramble for the Sahel
item.description: Algeria and Morocco are both seeking to fill the power vacuum that has emerged in the Sahel – long a theater for great-power rivalry. Each has a vision of bringing the region into its economic orbit, triggering a competition that could have profound strategic implications for the West.

item.title: What It Will Take to Beat the Far Right
item.description: The far right feeds on economic despair, insecurity, and exclusion. To starve it, those who want to preserve democracy must offer a counter-narrative oriented around dignity and belonging, and a policy program designed for economic inclusion and climate resilience.

item.title: South Korea’s Baby Bust
item.description: South Korea’s fertility crisis reflects not only economic constraints, but also a widening gap between social norms and women’s needs and aspirations. Only with bold, coordinated reforms that close this gap can the country raise fertility to a level that, though still below replacement, would avert demographic collapse.

item.title: How Can We Account for Crypto?
item.description: National income accounting has always been complicated by what happens in the underground and informal economies. Cryptocurrencies compound the problem, fueling money laundering and other illicit activities – and underscoring the need for more realistic measures of economic activity.

item.title: Why teenagers get involved in crime
item.description: Juvenile crime was not alien to Bangladesh society.
